One thing I do miss, however, is the ability to use stronger lightsaber attacks by timing your next move instead of button mashing.Overall, I love this game but wouldn't give it a perfect score.

												 A long time ago, in a galaxy of adorable little blocks...   Developer Traveller's Tales' LEGO games have never succeeded because they had the best puzzles or incredibly satisfying combat. In fact, in these regards, they were usually pretty mediocre. But they made up for the lack of awesome gameplay with adorable aesthetics and great use of the license. The latest, LEGO Star Wars III: The Clone Wars, continues the trend, immediately grabbing fans like me with its smart use of the subject matter and cute visuals, and kept me engaged despite its issues with its large mix of simplistic gameplay elements. The final combination is just good, simple fun.  LEGO Star Wars III: The Clone Wars covers seasons one and two of the popular animated series. Fans of the show get to act out their favorite moments (albeit as adorable LEGO characters), playing a variety of characters ranging from powerful Jedi to the lowliest droids. And like the other LEGO games, players have to use each character's unique abilities to overcome enemies and environmental puzzles. The puzzles and combat in LEGO Star Wars III aren't amazing. You might occasionally be surprised at a moment where a puzzle is genuinely clever, but they mostly either held my hand entirely or made the solution so obfuscated that they were frustrating rather than rewarding to solve. Likewise, the combat isn't all that exciting with its one-button-does-everything system. But, like so much of the LEGO games design, when you combine these two relatively unexciting portions together, something strange happens: It becomes a simple, engaging game. Maybe it's because together they break up the pacing and keep you in situations that are constantly forcing you to adapt, or perhaps it's because they're so easy to understand that you can kind of zone out and lose yourself to what's going on on-screen. Either way, I became lost to the grind of the adventure. And I enjoyed it. I would give it a 4.5 out of 10

												LEGO Star Wars III: Clone Wars was the first LEGO game where I often gut stuck for not easily understanding what I was supposed to do next. Once I had a bug where a level couldn't be finished and I had to restart it, and I had the game crash a few times. Additionally we see weak design carried over from older LEGO games. Besides those problems this is still a LEGO game and you can expect about the same amount of fun offered by previous LEGO games. Plus, there are a few new though very lightly implemented features which I enjoyed, e.g. the pseudo RTS ground battles and sort-of capture-the-flag space fights.+ Destroy and rebuild+ Pseudo-RTS elements+ Star system battles0 Hide-and-seek missions0 Still vanishing rewards but with acceptable time-outs- Studs falling behind walls- A few crashes- Buggy levels- No drop-shadows for coins, collectibles or characters- Bad information density on overviews/menus- Targeting of friendlies- Uneasy access to unlocked characters- Some confusing indicatorsWhen referring to old weak design I mean problems like missing drop-shadows making it hard (for me) to get a clear idea of the positions of game elements - vehicles of all sorts have drop-shadows though. Menus and most screens that could easily display relevant information that information is hidden in sub-menus or altogether denied, e.g. the pause screen during missions should always display the level name.There is a star map where each star has five data points, i.e. name, controlling faction and three completion states, only the first of which are available on the star map right away while the other three are hidden in each star's sub-menu. Admittedly they make sense in the sub-menus but should also be available outside.The hide-and-seek missions are okay. Basically, they are nice as a new idea and manage to avoid becoming boring by virtue of being pretty short.I like that collecting studs is easier here. Where in earlier LEGO games fighting often kept you from getting to your hard-earned studs in time, now you seem to have more time. Studs still fall behind walls or into the abyss though.Newer LEGO games offer direct access to unlocked characters at least in free play. This game has you run to sparsely distributed consoles, get the character you need to progress a puzzle, then run back to get the next character to solve it.Another old "feature" is the targeting of friendlies. I guess it's funny enough to punish your co-player from time to time but the concept makes absolutely no sense in single player mode. It feels almost as if the auto-aim - which in principle I agree is a sensible feature - prefers to aim at your sidekick rather than enemies or other sensible targets. This feeling may be due to my growing frustration with the effect and also the short distance your player 2 unnecessarily keeps.As usual you'll be able to obtain indicators that help you find red bricks and minikits. But sometimes the indication is pretty far off, indicating where you find the minikit rather than where you need to get it.Despite all the problems I still immensely enjoyed playing LEGO Star Wars III: Clone Wars and I recommend it without hesitation. If you had fun with other, specifically older LEGO games you should be sufficiently entertained by this one.

												Lego Star Wars 3 is the black sheep in the series. It seems like Traveller's Tales wanted to experiment a bit with this one. Many levels feel like Battlefront space battles (you get on and off your ship repeatedly), some levels are a simplified RTS game, the Hub is huge and expands as you explore it with new abilities... And that's not counting some new gameplay mechanics, such as the lightsaber throw. You would think that with that many new features, it would be the most awesome game in the series. The thing is, it's not. The "Battlefront space battles" are quite amazing, but other than that everything feels off. The RTS parts are fun at first, but it feels quickly repetitive and not very clever (there are a too many levels like that to my taste). The Hub is just too big, and looking for a character you need to progress in it is a pain and can take a lot of time. Also, it's not always clear where you have to go or what you have to do. It's supposed to be a children game, but I often found myself stuck for a while. Walking in circles trying to find the next objective is really tedious and should not be a part of this game.But the worst of all is that TT found a way to mess up with the coop part. Coop multiplayer is arguably the biggest selling point of the Lego games; ask anyone who love their game, and there's a big chance they'll tell you they love playing them with their partner, their friend or their kid. But in Lego Star Wars 3, their are phases where the two players are not even in the same room, and they have to do different tasks. It doesn't feel like they're playing together. And above that, one of the two players will often have less things to do than the other, so it's just a dull phase when they do nothing and have to wait for the other. Why do I still recommend it, you ask? Well first thing, I'm sure that if you play it alone, it's a much better game. If so, I'm sure it's amazing. But even if you play with someone else like I did, the "classic" phases are as fun as ever (when you're not seperated, that is), the RTS ones are at least nice to discover, and in the case of the space battles they're quite fun the whole game. Also, the humor is enjoyable. It's not as great as the humor in Complete Saga, and some of the jokes are a bit too random, but it's good and certainly better than what you have in some of the most recent voiced games (looking at you, Lego Marvel).

For me, they are my "relaxer" games.So it is without hesitation that I recommend Lego Star Wars III: The Clone Wars to any and all Lego fans and Star Wars fans, as well as fans of goofy, exciting fun that isn't too much of a challenge.Pros:- Fun, colorful graphics.- Loads of entertainment for anyone of any age.- Hours and hours and hours of playability and replayability.- Legitimately funny cutscenes and Lego antics.- A HUGE central hub.- A huge number of characters to unlock and play around with.- As best I could tell (based mainly upon the fact that I am not quite caught up with TCW television series at the time of writing this review), the missions are faithful to the series.Cons:- Literally the worst Lego character creator I have seen yet. 												The fourth game in the lego star wars series, Lego star wars 3 is a special one since it's about the Clone Wars cartoon instead of the movies. I wish this game was made a little bit later but not too late since some of the cooler episodes were not out yet when the game was made, but i also like that they still have grunts and moans instead of voice acting.what is new in this game?You choose what missions you want to start with instead of going on a linear path. you play episode to episode. The best part about it is that it's in actual chronological order! yes you heard that. the game actually follows the story in chronological order unlike the show which released the episodes in a random order!There are more features such as gold bricks that have to be destroyed with rapid fire weapons, throwable lightsabers, combo moves, quick time events, and more. i'll talk about the biggest ones next.There is now a bigger hub ship with tons of rooms to unlock and secrets to be discovered. Once you open up the hangar you can actually take a ship and fly to the seperatist ship and change hubs to the evil side where you can buy separatist characters and ships AND even play sith side missions!The other big mission features are ground battles where the game throws you into an empty and big level with areas to build bases and turrets. You attack and take over other bases by making troop barracks sort of like a RTS but you get to battle too. There are now more customizable characters than the usual 2 we saw in lego star wars 2 and complete saga. The music is taken from the episodes the missions take place in so no more do we have repeated tracks from the movies in every single enemy encounter, every episode has different music. Like i mentioned before the game is based on the show , but it's based on the first seasons. The clones are still in phase 2 so there are no episode 3 ships or clone troopers like we see later in the show. OVERALL is this game better than 2? in features and gameplay yes! but for those people who never bothered to watch The clone wars cartoon they might not like the setting. the humor is still here! the cutscenes are longer then before and    even a little bit better. the characters now have more face expersions which give them more personality.another thing that will make you enjoy the game is the lack of the pointless voice acting that started with lego batman 2. The silence of the characters make it funnier and their own style. Graphics are more shiny than before and the characters more detailed. GET THIS GAME IF YOU ARE A FAN.!! my rating would be a 9/10

												Personally, even I don't know why I'm giving this game a negative review. Maybe I'm just spoiled on what Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga already delivered...Naaaaaah!Lego Star Wars III- The Clone Wars is the next game Traveler's Tales was contractually obligated to make from Star Wars, before they'd lose the rights, which I'm sure they're refreshing with their new release for The Force Awakens. And, as always, there's a problem with the Traveler's Tales Lego games that seems to have started with this entry...Traveler's Tales doesn't believe in patience. At all.Why wait for us to do a complete Indiana Jones, when we could release two? I know! Let's also release Lego The Hobbit within months of Battle of the Five Armies, but not include it in out game! Wait! I've got another idea! How about we make Lego Star Wars: The Force Awakens, before the other two entries are even made!It's sad, honestly. I really like certain elements of LSW III that I do like. The new characters and locations inspired from the Clone Wars film and TV series are all fun to play as, beautifully animated, and great to control. There's tons of new abilities available, allowing tons of new opportunities for puzzles, such as mnigun targets, grappling, and precise Force movements.However, this feels like a really shoddy attempt to give these new abilities so light to shine in. There were a fair share of puzzles in the original LSW games that didn't outright tell you the answer, but you could figure them out with your own deduction skills. But with the way the puzzles are set up for the new abilities, it's always obvious what you have to do next.On top of that, if Traveler's Tales had waited for the ENTIRE series to finish its run, they would have had a lot more opportunities at their hands. Hundreds of characters, tons of new planets to choose from, and even more abilities you could create.But it really feels like they chose the most boring planets to visit. Out of all the levels I played, I only liked Ambush, Rookies, Lair of Grievous, Hostage Crisis, and Castle of Doom for their aesthetics. 5 out of about 25 levels. Because most of them are either space levels, running around dark, metal corridors, or battlefiels in the middle of a desert.Where's the snowy tundras of "Trespass"? Where's the swamps of Rodia from "Bombad Jedi"? The massive fungal world from "Bounty Hunters"? It doesn't feel like TT chose the most creative or unique planets from the show to focus on. Along with that, I'm not the biggest fan of the massive battle levels. They might have been better in the match mode, but from the story mode, it's a very one-sided fight with some simple building mechanics, that would've worked better if you could select bases at once, instead of running to the base you want to build on, and then building there.However, I did enjoy the space levels for their new enhancements to the original level design set up in LSW II. Now, you don't just fly around and shoot down enemies, you also can fly into cruisers, and take out individual droids and solve puzzles as a normal character. It has the Battlefront II feel to it, that I enjoy.I also enjoy the new minikit feature, where they actually unlock different character to play as... but that leads into one of my biggest complains for the game... The Hub. It sucks. It absolutely sucks. It's far too large. Everything is spread too far apart, so it's a drudgery to get to another side of the ship to buy a new vehicle you unlocked. Or if you forgot a specific character to solve a puzzle, you'll have to find another character-selector and then return to solve the puzzle. I mean, hell, there's an entire space zone between the Republic and Separatist cruisers, if you want to go all the way to the other side of the Hub to unlock the villain characters. In layman's terms, this sh** is spread too far apart.And while I do like the new minikit feature to unlock character, I don't like the lack of creativity spent in hiding the minikits- especially in the battle levels. It gets so predictable, that it gets flat out boring to collect all the minikits, or frustrating if you make a small mistake, and suddenly a section of the level is blocked off and you'll have to reset (but you can save what progress you've made- which I do like).I'm giving Lego Star Wars III- The Clone wars a 5/10. It's a massive mixed bag filled with tons of new things I like a LOT... but a ton of other things that felt like Traveler's Tales was just going through the motions in making another Lego Star Wars game. It's not bad, per se, but it doesn't have enough good features to make it distinguishable from the rest of the Lego video game library.

												I don't feel it is a great choice if you are new to the lego game series.didn't get on with this game. I have no idea what i'm suppose to be doing most of the time. The instructions are non existent, i've tried exploring a bit and still, every part of the game seems to leave me in a room with no instruction as to how to get out. I keep getting hint messages telling me what to do.. but still nothing happens when i try and do it. definitely not a game for those who have never played the lego games before. presume you need to be experienced with them before this is any funEDIT:Perhaps I need to clarify a few things that I said above. I'm not saying that the game itself is bad, I can see it is highly regarded by others as a good game. The puzzle solving concept with a lego, star wars theme is right up my street. The problem I have with this game is that I don't feel it is a great choice if you are new to the lego game series. This is the message I wanted to get across to people. I understand that it is a sequel to existing games, however, I would have liked there to be a simple (perhaps optional) tutorial that gently walks a person through the games concepts so that I could play this game without having played any others in the lego series.Consider my situation and then my experience with the game.I am someone who has never played any lego game before, I do not have a spouse or sibling here with me to give me a brief overview of how to play the game. The first thing I do is click start game. I then watch a 2 minute video that sets the scene and the game begins. The game expects me to know(1) what the game controls are (I think a lot of people will tend to have a brief look before they play, like I did, but I expect many will like to figure most of this stuff out as they play). (2) Knowledge about switching players(3) What actions each character can do (4) Know how the use special actions with certain characters (e.g. using the force to push an object)I feel that this is already quite a lot to have to know about, and then on top of all this, if I don't figure all of this out within a 3 minute time period, the characters get attacked by monsters and I failed that bit of the level. I then get put back to the start menu and click play game, I have to sit through the same 2 minute video again because there didn't appear to be an obvious way to skip it.I do this 3 or 4 times, before I google how to escape this first scene. I would say that’s a pretty poor introduction to a game... And the game goes on, without the time pressure element, but still there is little guidance for the kind of things I'm expected to do. I would say that the game hasn't given me the right opportunities to established a thought process that I need, that will allow me to explore the ideas ive already been introduced to, and using what ive learnt to complete new challenges.Now, I believe that if the game designers target audience were new players who had never played any lego game before, this first sequence would never have passed testing! I think they would have put greater focus on a step-by-step learning process within the opening challenges of the game before the player is thrown in at the deep end. There are no tutorial level and very little in terms of introducing players to the game concepts. I therefore have to assume that the designers of the game were intending this to be a game for more experienced players.That is all there is to it. I think that if I had known this before purchasing the game, I would definetly have bought a different game from the lego series. One that would allow a beginner to have a good time.

												As a massive fan of both Star Wars and the LEGO game franchise of course I'm gonna love this. If you've played any of the other LEGO games you pretty much know a lot of the basics you're gonna find here. It's a great time, although I did find it infinitely more frustrating than any of the others. You can play the game in pretty much any order you want. There are three branching "chapters" if you will. One centered around Count Dooku, one centered around Asajj Ventress, and one centered around General Grievous. There's no specific order you have to play the levels in, but it almost feels like the game wants you to play them in a certain order, and I can't figure out quite what that order is. There were levels I would play and feel almost lost. There is very little explanation of what you're supposed to do, which is a surprising rarity for the series. While I like not being obnoxiously prompted toward everything and enjoy some challenge, there have already been some times I've had to check game guides to figure out how in the world to do certain things. Destroying gold structures, for instance, requires you to hit them with rapid fire or a consistent laser beam. And I only know that because I looked it up. Not once in five hours has the game told me that, which seems a detriment, especially since the game is meant for kids. However despite that it is a load of fun, and the newly added RTS levels feel very thematically appropriate, since the Clone Wars is, well, war. It works well with the story, and once you know what you're doing it's an absolute blast. Honestly my biggest problem is that it's really buggy for me for some reason, which has kept me from being able to complete certain levels. In one R2-D2 wouldn't hover no matter how hard I tried to make him, and in one Captain Rex completely disappeared after a while, right when I realized he was the only character I had who I needed anymore. 												My 3~4yo son loves it.Pros:- very charming characters and tons of them;- Tons of things to do, the main hub is huge and you can travel between separatist and republic ships;- Codes to unlock new characters, so you don't have to play the whole thing, tho it's really fun to get the mini-kits and see the kids excitement for the new character.Cons:- The game isn't intuitive at all, actually, it's counter intuitive, be prepared to check guides and stare to the screen for a while to find out what you have to do; - The split screen is great to play with the kids, tho it can get messy with you need to hit targets that are too far away; - Jedis are overpowered and I hate to play with non-jedi toons.The main problem is that the game is counter intuitive, but I have heard that most of lego games are like that. Otherwise is really amusing!
